cards.title: 2018 World Cup / Russia cuts budget by £340m

item.title: Russia cuts 2018 World Cup budget by £340m amid cost-cutting measures
item.trailText: The Russian government has cut the budget for the 2018 World Cup by £340m as part of belt-tightening measures, even though stadium construction projects have reportedly been over cost and behind schedule
item.standFirst:
• Total planned cost is now down to £7.4bn
• ‘It’s a question of optimising the preparations,’ says sports minister
item.body:
The Russian government has cut the budget for the 2018 World Cup by £340m as part of belt-tightening measures, even though stadium construction projects have reportedly been over cost and behind schedule.

A decree by the prime minister, Dmitry Medvedev, published on Monday reduced the World Cup budget, including both government and private expenditures, by 29.2 billion roubles. The total planned cost is now 631.5 billion roubles (£7.4bn).

“Of course it’s a question of optimising the preparations. We’re primarily taking out the excess hotels,” the sports minister, Vitaly Mutko, told the state news agency R-Sport on Monday.

Related: Putin says Fifa's granting of World Cup to Russia 'should not be questioned'

Mutko said Russia was cutting “redundant” construction projects and had agreed with Fifa to reduce the number of hotels and other facilities planned for the World Cup. The number of training facilities at each stadium will now be three rather than four, he said.

“This is a reflection of the difficult economic situation but it should not have a negative effect on the event itself,” Dmitry Yefimov, a Fifa representative in Russia, told R-Sport.

Even before the reduction there were doubts that Russia could meet its World Cup budget, since the cost for the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics grew exponentially during construction, eventually reaching an estimated $50bn.

The Russian government has implemented a 10% across-the-board budget cut this year amid reduced revenues from low oil prices. Despite suggestions Russia could be stripped of the World Cup if corruption is found during ongoing investigations, the president Vladimir Putin this weekend reiterated his commitment to holding the event, noting that stadium construction had already started. The Guardian reported this month that at least 40% of the World Cup construction programme was under way or has been completed.

But in an investigation published on Sunday, the respected newspaper Vedomosti reported that at least half of Russia’s World Cup stadiums were behind schedule and almost all were over budget this spring, quoting an unnamed stadium designer. In particular, the rouble crisis of last year, when the currency lost more than half its value against the dollar, caused prices for largely imported equipment to rocket. According to Mikhail Khryapov, director of Stroitransgaz, which is building the stadiums in Volgograd and Nizhny Novgorod, equipment prices rose by 50% and the overall cost of the project increased by 15%.

In addition, World Cup construction has run into unforeseen costs and delays. For instance, builders in Russia’s Kaliningrad exclave had to spend 850 million roubles on sand to firm up the swampy ground where the World Cup stadium there is supposed to be constructed.

As a result of delays and price overruns, the sports ministry allowed contractors and builders to simplify the designs, Vedomosti reported. A spokesperson for the first deputy prime minister, Igor Shuvalov, said stadium projects were cancelling extra features, using cheaper technologies, replacing imported products with local ones and re-examining contracts to try to cut out middlemen. At the same time all of Fifa’s quality and safety requirements would still be met, he said.

Previously Fifa has allowed Russian organisers to reduce the planned capacity of World Cup stadium projects in Kaliningrad, Volgograd and Yekaterinburg to 35,000 rather than the standard 40,000.

In a separate interview with the newspaper, Aras Agalarov, the president of Crocus Group, which is building the stadiums in Kaliningrad and Rostov-on-Don, said that after prices began to rise, he received permission from the government to “optimise” these projects to fit the previously planned budget. For instance, the number of elevators planned at the Rostov-on-Don stadium was reduced from 45 to 25, he said.

According to the Vedomosti report, government agencies and building companies have claimed they were able to save significantly by replacing imports and making projects more efficient. Not all imports can be replaced, since some complicated electronics and other components are not made in Russia. But Chinese companies often produce copies of European components, and buying from them instead can reduce costs by 15% or more compared with European stadiums, according to Delovaya Rossiya, a civic organisation that promotes an open business climate.

displayImages.caption: The Russian sports minister, Vitaly Mutko, said costs for the 2018 World Cup will be reduced by. among other measures, dispensing with excess hotels and reducing the number of training facilities. Photograph: Maxim Zmeyev/Reuters
displayImages.cleanCaption: The Russian sports minister, Vitaly Mutko, said costs for the 2018 World Cup will be reduced by. among other measures, dispensing with excess hotels and reducing the number of training facilities. Photograph: Maxim Zmeyev/Reuters

cards.title: Everton / Garbutt to sign five-year deal to stay at Goodison
cards.rawTitle: Garbutt to sign five-year deal to stay at Goodison

item.title: Everton’s Luke Garbutt to sign five-year deal to stay at Goodison
item.trailText: Luke Garbutt will play on loan at Bournemouth after signing a five-year deal at Everton
item.standFirst:
• Left-back will spend the season on loan at Bournemouth
• Garbutt with England Under-21s at European Championship
item.body:
Luke Garbutt is to sign a new five-year contract at Everton and then move to Bournemouth on a season-long loan.

The England Under-21 left-back, who left Leeds United for Goodison Park in 2009, had appeared likely to depart after negotiations stalled. However, with the 22-year-old’s contract due to expire next week, he has agreed terms through to 2020. He will return to Everton to challenge Leighton Baines for the left-back spot in 2016-17.

Garbutt has played in both of England Under-21s’ group games at the European Championship but his involvement at Everton has been limited to five Premier League appearances and a handful of Europa League games. There have also been loan spells at Cheltenham and Colchester, though he will challenge Charlie Daniels for a starting place in Bournemouth’s first top-flight campaign.

Both Bournemouth and Swansea City had expressed an interest in securing Garbutt on a permanent deal, their hopes having briefly risen when the player was omitted from Roberto Martínez’s match-day squad for the final two games of the domestic season despite injuries to Baines and Bryan Oviedo.

displayImages.caption: Luke Garbutt of Everton is challenged by Sergei Petrov of Krasnodar during December's Europa League game at Gooodison Park. Photograph: Alex Livesey/Getty Images

cards.title: West Brom / McClean jumps at chance to leave Wigan and sign three-year deal
cards.rawTitle: McClean jumps at chance to leave Wigan and sign three-year deal

item.title: James McClean jumps at chance to sign three-year deal with West Brom
item.trailText: Republic of Ireland’s winger James McClean is relishing a Premier League return after moving from Wigan to West Brom in a three-year deal for an undisclosed fee
item.standFirst:
• Ireland winger relishes Premier League return with ‘stable club’
• McClean: ‘Tony Pulis told me his plans and where I would fit in’
item.body:
West Bromwich Albion have made the winger James McClean their first signing of the summer. The 26-year-old has joined from the League One side Wigan Athletic for an undisclosed fee and is tied to West Brom for three years, with the club retaining an option to extend the deal for a further 12 months.

The Republic of Ireland international told West Brom’s website: “I’m delighted. I’ve played in the Premier League before [with Sunderland] and not only am I back here but I’m with a stable top-flight club and one that wants to push on.

“Tony Pulis told me what his plans were, where I would fit in. It was all very positive. The Premier League is where any player wants to be.”

McClean finished last season as Wigan’s top scorer in the Championship with six goals and was voted the club’s player of the year but was powerless to stop Wigan being relegated to League One.

cards.title: Southampton / Keeper Stekelenburg arrives on loan from Fulham
cards.rawTitle: Keeper Stekelenburg arrives on loan from Fulham

item.title: Southampton sign goalkeeper Maarten Stekelenburg on loan from Fulham
item.trailText: Southampton have acquired the Holland goalkeeper Maarten Stekelenburg on a season-long loan from Fulham to provide cover for the injured Fraser Forster
item.standFirst:
• The 32-year-old will act as cover for the injured Fraser Forster
• Stekelenburg’s European and international experience key, says Les Reed
item.body:
Southampton have acquired the Holland goalkeeper Maarten Stekelenburg on a season-long loan from Fulham to provide cover for the injured Fraser Forster.

The Saints needed to make a move after Forster damaged his left patellar tendon in March – an injury which he is expected to take up to a year to recover from.

Stekelenburg, capped 54 times, spent last season on loan at Monaco after Fulham’s relegation to the Championship.

Related: Southampton sign Sporting Lisbon’s Cédric Soares on a four-year contract

The 32-year-old made only four appearances for Monaco as he failed to dislodge Danijel Subasic and he is now hoping to find regular football at St Mary’s.

“I’m very pleased that I’ve joined,” he said on Southampton’s website. “It’s a big, nice club that will play European football and I can play. Last year I didn’t play a lot, so it’s an opportunity for me. I’m grateful. The last two years weren’t the best of my career. As they say in England: the best is yet to come.”

Stekelenburg joined Fulham from Roma in 2013. He began his career by coming through the ranks at Ajax and became Holland’s goalkeeper after Edwin van der Sar’s retirement before the 2010 World Cup. He has not played for the national team since October 2012.

Southampton are hoping that his experience can help them at home and in Europe. “Maarten is a goalkeeper with a wealth of top-level experience who will prove to be an important addition to the squad at this early stage of pre-season,” Southampton’s executive director of football, Les Reed, said.

“While Fraser Forster’s rehabilitation is progressing well, adding Maarten to our squad alongside Kelvin Davis and Paulo Gazzaniga will give us strength in depth for what will be a busy season.

“Maarten enjoyed tremendous success in Holland with Ajax and on the international stage, playing in the 2010 World Cup final. His experience will be invaluable to us, especially with the arrival of European football. There was strong competition for Maarten’s services, so we are very pleased he has committed to our cause.”

displayImages.altText: File photo dated 09-02-2014 of Maarten Stekelenburg, Fulham goalkeeper. PRESS ASSOCIATION Photo. Issue date: Monday June 22, 2015. Southampton have brought in Holland goalkeeper Maarten Stekelenburg on a season-long loan from Fulham to provide cover for the injured Fraser Forster. See PA story SOCCER Southampton Stekelenburg. cards.title: Norwich sign West Brom midfielder Youssouf Mulumbu on free transfer
cards.rawTitle: Norwich sign West Brom midfielder Youssouf Mulumbu on free transfer

item.title: Norwich sign West Brom midfielder Youssouf Mulumbu on free transfer
item.trailText: Norwich have signed the former West Bromwich Albion midfielder Youssouf Mulumbu on a free transfer, their second signing of the summer after securing Graham Dorrans
item.standFirst:
• Mulumbu joins Graham Dorrans in arriving at newly promoted Norwich
• ‘He has vast experience of the Premier League,’ says Alex Neil
item.body:
Norwich have signed the former West Bromwich Albion midfielder Youssouf Mulumbu on a free transfer. The 28-year-old DR Congo international will join on 1 July when his contract at The Hawthorns expires.

Mulumbu becomes the second signing by Norwich since their victory in the Championship play-off final, with the Scotland midfielder Graham Dorrans already making his move from West Brom permanent.

Related: Graham Dorrans joins Norwich from West Brom on permanent deal after loan

Alex Neil, who guided Norwich back to the Premier League after taking over in January, believes Mulumbu will bring with him invaluable experience.

“The fact that we have been able to pick Youssouf up on a free transfer is a fantastic piece of business,” Neil said. “His arrival will add to the competition for places. We have a strong squad with a lot of players that have done well in the Premier League and Youssouf will bring that competition to the squad.

“He has vast experience of the Premier League, but he is still at a good age. You generally say that a player comes into their peak between 27 and 32, and he is right in the middle of that. He is another fantastic player to add to an already strong squad going into the Premier League.”

displayImages.altText: File photo dated 09-11-2014 of West Bromwich Albion's Youssouf Mulumbu. PRESS ASSOCIATION Photo. Issue date: Monday June 22, 2015. Norwich have confirmed the signing of former West Brom midfielder Youssouf Mulumbu on a free transfer. See PA story SOCCER Norwich. Photo credit should read David Davies/PA Wire.

headerImage.caption: Youssouf Mulumbu will become Norwich’s second signing of the summer when his West Brom contract expires on 1 July. Photograph: David Davies/PA

cards.title: England U21s / Pritchard to miss rest of European Championship
cards.rawTitle: Pritchard to miss rest of European Championship

item.title: England Under-21s’ Alex Pritchard to miss remainder of Euros
item.trailText: The midfielder Alex Pritchard will not play any further part in the European Championship after sustaining an ankle injury
item.standFirst:
• Midfielder picked up ankle injury in 1-0 win against Sweden
• John Stones expected to return for Italy match after concussion
item.body:
England suffered their third injury setback of the European Under-21 Championship when Alex Pritchard was ruled out by an ankle injury.

The Tottenham midfielder was withdrawn during the 1-0 win over Sweden on Sunday and scans have revealed significant damage.

England had already lost Saido Berahino to a knee injury in training before the team’s opening game against Portugal and suspected concussion cost the services of John Stones for that game and the Sweden match. Stones is fit to return in the make-or-break final group game with Italy on Wednesday.

Pritchard, who spent last season on loan at Brentford, had impressed during a substitute appearance against Portugal and when promoted to the starting XI for the win over Sweden, although his replacement against the Swedes, Jesse Lingard, scored the only goal of the game.

Wolves’ Benik Afobe was called up to replace Berahino but no one can be called into the squad to replace Pritchard because competition rules prevent additions after the first match.

displayImages.caption: Alex Pritchard, in action against Sweden, will not play any further part for Gareth Southgate's Under-21s in Czech Republic. Photograph: Peter Powell/EPA

cards.title: West Ham return for longest of seasons after the shortest of summers
cards.rawTitle: West Ham return for longest of seasons after the shortest of summers

item.title: West Ham return for longest of seasons after the shortest of summers
item.trailText: West Ham are back in training this week and while Slaven Bilic wants to begin with a feelgood run in the Europa League, the co-chairman David Sullivan knows they must not risk their Premier League status
item.standFirst: Slaven Bilic’s squad are back in training this week and while the new manager wants to begin with a feelgood run in the Europa League, the co-chairman David Sullivan knows they must not risk Premier League status
item.body:
By the time West Ham begin their Premier League season they may have already played 11 matches. Such is the remarkable situation Slaven Bilic walks into, a summer like no other and the last season at Upton Park, where stability for at least another year is paramount.

Bilic’s new job started in earnest on Monday when along with a significant proportion of the first-team squad he began preparations for the longest of campaigns. Most English clubs do not return for another couple of weeks but West Ham, because of Europa League commitments, have called players back early as they try to navigate what their co-chairman David Sullivan describes as a “nightmare” schedule.

Related: Slaven Bilic must show West Ham he is more than a rock star manager | Aleksandar Holiga

For Sullivan and co, however, it is a nightmare they are embracing, one which has provided a shot at European football and the opportunity for Bilic to begin with an immediate feelgood run. The consequences further down the line, though, are potentially treacherous.

West Ham qualified for the 2015-16 Europa League through Uefa’s fair play ranking, ensuring a first European season for nine years despite finishing 12th in the Premier League. But to reach the group stage of the competition they will need to play eight matches, six before the start of the English domestic season and then a two-leg play-off.

The first of Uefa’s three, two-leg qualifying rounds starts a week on Thursday and West Ham were on Monday drawn against FC Lusitans of Andorra. To say it has caused complications for the club is an understatement. West Ham have had to arrange a full pre-season programme alongside the European fixtures, in many ways a contingency plan should they depart the competition early while also providing extra fitness practice for those not ready for competitive action.

Their pre-season fixtures begin against Peterborough on 11 July and include games against Southend, Colchester, Charlton, Norwich and possibly Werder Bremen, when youth players will get more of a run-out than normal. “The most difficult thing is the pre-season because you don’t know what round you are going to get knocked out in,” Sullivan said. “You have to have fixtures lined up in case you are knocked out. We’ve got a full pre-season of games and we have to juggle players between that with European competition.

Related: Europa League draw: West Ham to play FC Lusitans of Andorra

“It’s a nightmare really but it’s fascinating and fun. It will be the most meaningful pre-season because instead of playing just friendlies where the results don’t matter, you’re playing games where the results do matter. It’s very exciting but quite arduous and quite complicated to work out a strategy. It’s a nightmare but what can you do?

“It’s also a dream, another route to the Champions League. We’d be 1,000-1 to get that. Success is participation, giving fans a taste of Europe. We’ll be pricing the games to sell them out and anticipate very large gates from the early rounds on. Our supporters are very excited.”

Given that West Ham finished the 2014-15 season only four weeks ago, it is quite a turnaround. If they advance to the third qualifying round of the Europa League, the second leg of which is scheduled for 6 August, their first Premier League game of the new season against Arsenal will have to be played on either the Sunday or Monday after the opening Saturday.

Such is the need for players that Mauro Zárate, who spent last season on loan at QPR, has been recalled. The Argentinian’s deal with QPR was due to run until 1 July but West Ham are in urgent need of numbers. Enner Valencia, meanwhile, has beenon international duty with Ecuador at the Copa América.

Any new signings cannot be registered for the first round of Europa League qualifying, so West Ham are set to line up with a patchwork side until other players return. Those who featured heavily last season did not begin training on Monday and have been given extra time to rest. They will not attend a pre-season camp in Ireland that was arranged by Sam Allardyce, Bilic’s predecessor.

This is a pivotal season for the club, one that will end with a move to the Olympic Stadium and which, for West Ham’s future health, must end with Premier League safety assured. Most other clubs do not start their preparations for a number of days, Tottenham’s players returning on 3 July, Manchester City’s on 7 July and Chelsea’s on 15 July.

No team have won the Europa League from the first qualifying round since the rebranding of the tournament in 2009, a feat that would require participation in 23 matches. When Fulham reached the 2010 final they played 18 matches, having begun at the third qualifying stage.

Indeed, the knock-on effect for English teams is usually negative on the domestic front, with many struggling to adapt to the Thursday-Sunday sequence of fixtures. Dr Andrew Hill, a leading academic expert in burnout, described the potential psychological impact that an extended season could have.

“You could argue that starting earlier and playing more fixtures is associated with greater psychological stress,” said Hill. “You have to prepare for more games, deal with the successes and failures associated with those games. Potentially, the more fixtures you play and the more congested it becomes, you’re experiencing higher levels of stress and have less time to recover.”

Sullivan said: “There is an element of risk. Traditionally English teams who play in this competition don’t do that well. It seems to be an English disease that we can’t play on the Thursday and the Sunday.”

Financially, the Europa League is far less rewarding than the Champions League. West Ham will receive £1.7m (€2.4m) if they reach the group stage, where they receive €360,000 for a win and €120,000 for a draw. The teams competing in the group stage of the Champions League receive €12m.

The opportunity for supporters to travel across Europe is one many are relishing, even if the financial rewards for the club are relatively insignificant. According to Alison Worth, formerly of the West Ham Supporter Advisory Board and in the process of creating an independent supporters’ association, the excitement is mixed with an air of trepidation.

“I’m old enough to remember the old European excitement and I think it’s wonderful for the fans and a great experience,” she said. “But we don’t have a full squad at the moment, we are quite short in key areas. It could go dramatically wrong, that is my concern. There is a real split between fans over 40 and those younger ones. As much as the older supporters are loving being in Europe, we know we can’t afford to let our Premier League status be questioned in any way. It’s a double-edged sword, because I haven’t been this excited for a number of years.”
